lightning struck house, making hole in wall

within a month, 8 years earlier

witnesses.relationship_to_accused: brother of Claude who was allegedly bewitched

testimony.quarrel_subject: killing of hen by brother after Jacquot's hens continually damaged garden; Jacquot knocked unripe apples off trees
testimony.threat_quote: would give Claude such a blow he would knock him to the ground if he met him

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: after threat to mother when she complained

testimony.quarrel_subject: his son Jean aged 6 called Jacquot's daughter 'noir bo' in play or annoyance

Jacquot Petit Jacquot and his wife

5 or 6 years earlier, after Jacquot mounted small son on it

timeline.subject: Jacquot Petit Jacquot
timeline.details: PG des Vosges received information that accused is selling all his goods in fear of arrest and denunciation by witches held at Mirecourt; asked for arrest and taking of depositions

timeline.subject: Jacquot Petit Jacquot
timeline.details: Receveur of Mirecourt received information that Jacquot had returned home secretly to settle affairs; went with 6 men and captured him on road to Bazoilles

timeline.subject: Jacquot Petit Jacquot
timeline.details: First interrogation; said he was 55, draper, living at Lorquin; denied leaving in fear of witchcraft arrest

timeline.subject: Jacquot Petit Jacquot
timeline.details: Confrontations with witnesses; accused made reproaches against several witnesses

timeline.subject: Jacquot Petit Jacquot
timeline.details: Continuation of confrontations; all reproaches denied by witnesses

timeline.subject: Jacquot Petit Jacquot
timeline.details: Third interrogation; said he left because he was vilified and when anyone had illness they said it was him

timeline.subject: Jacquot Petit Jacquot
timeline.details: PG des Vosges asks for question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Jacquot Petit Jacquot
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture; withstood thumbscrews, rack, and tortillons without confessing; called on patron saints and promised pilgrimage to N.D. de Liesse; questioned briefly next day, stood by denials

timeline.subject: Jacquot Petit Jacquot
timeline.details: PG des Vosges proposes that he be renvoyé (released)

prior_accusations.accuser_name: Dedier André (also Didier André, Dedier Andreu)
prior_accusations.context: Quarrelled with Jacquot over a garden, then animals died daily and he sold garden; animals still died, then illness spread to family with 6 people dying; André accused Jacquot of wanting to ruin him; André was later ruined with his children before his death
Jacquot feared denunciation by witches currently held at Mirecourt in March 1623

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacquot Petit Jacquot
notable_quotes.french: qu'il ne luy en tueroit plus, sans se repentir
notable_quotes.english: that he wouldn't kill any more without repenting
notable_quotes.context: Threat to Jeannotte after her brother Claude killed Jacquot's hen

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacquot Petit Jacquot
notable_quotes.context: To his daughter when she pointed out a great black bull in the fields, which then disappeared

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacquot Petit Jacquot
notable_quotes.context: About Françoise, during quarrel with Mengeotte

notable_quotes.speaker: Françoise
notable_quotes.french: (replied that he had put it there)
notable_quotes.english: (replied that he had put it there)
notable_quotes.context: Reply to Jacquot's accusation that she had 'le diable au corps'

notable_quotes.speaker: Dedier André (via hearsay)
notable_quotes.french: le plus pauvre homme de sa race
notable_quotes.english: the poorest man of his race
notable_quotes.context: Threat by Jacquot that he would make Dedier André the poorest man of his race

notable_quotes.speaker: Messire Jean Chrestofle (priest/vicaire)
notable_quotes.french: que sy ce n'estoit la honte du monde qu'il se feroit apprehender pour le crime de sortilege
notable_quotes.english: that if it were not for the shame of the world he would have himself arrested for the crime of witchcraft
notable_quotes.context: Jacquot allegedly declared this to the former vicaire of Hymont, now at Mirecourt

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacquot Petit Jacquot
notable_quotes.context: Said when emerging to see what was happening after Pierot Poirson was injured by log and wild horse

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacquot Petit Jacquot
notable_quotes.french: que si sa femme l'eust voulu croire, il eut enduré tout ce que l'on auroit voulu, mais que sa femme l'a tousjours dechassée pour conserver l'honneur de leur fille, laquelle ne peult qu'elle ne recoipvre deshonneur a cause qu'il est ainsy fugitif
notable_quotes.english: that if his wife had wanted to believe him, he would have endured all that would have been wanted, but that his wife had always chased him away to preserve the honor of their daughter, who cannot help but receive dishonor because he is thus a fugitive
notable_quotes.context: Statement to Claudon femme Demenge le Clerc at last Christmas about why he fled

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacquot Petit Jacquot
notable_quotes.french: qu'il y avoit beaucoup d'artz de sortileges a Hymont desquels il n'estoit la cause, mais qu'il en nommeroit les autheurs qu'en il seroit temps
notable_quotes.english: that there were many arts of witchcraft at Hymont of which he was not the cause, but that he would name the authors when it was time
notable_quotes.context: Allegedly said since arrest (but denied by Jacquot in interrogation)

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacquot Petit Jacquot
notable_quotes.french: a cause qu'il estoit vilipendé du monde et que quand quelqu'un avoit quelque maladie qu'on disoit que c'avoit esté luy et fut tellement indigné de tant de discours communs qu'il fut contraint d'aller trouver le taincturier de Lorquin pour travailler avec luy
notable_quotes.english: because he was vilified by the world and when anyone had any illness they said it was him and was so indignant at so many common rumors that he was forced to go find the dyer of Lorquin to work with him
notable_quotes.context: Explanation for why he left Hymont during 26 August 1624 interrogation

notable_quotes.speaker: Messire Poirson (mayeur)
notable_quotes.french: que Messire Poirson luy avoit deffendu d'en prendre la vengeance, et qu'un jour s'ayant addressé a luy comme chef de justice contre un particulier qui l'avoit appelé sorcier, les feit tenir tous deux hommes de bien et allerent boire ensembles avec l'eschevin
notable_quotes.english: that Messire Poirson had forbidden him from taking vengeance, and that one day having addressed him as head of justice against a particular person who had called him witch, he made them both be held as good men and they went drinking together with the alderman
notable_quotes.context: Jacquot's explanation for why he did not take legal action against those who called him witch

notable_quotes.speaker: Mongin André (via his widow)
notable_quotes.french: qu'il avoit entré deans leur lict une beste de longueur d'un homme qui s'estoit mise sur luy, et tellement pesant qu'il n'esut le pouvoir de faire le signe de la croix avec sa main, ains du bout de la langue, et qu'il l'avoit veu entrer par la clanche de la porte a la lueur de la lune
notable_quotes.english: that there had entered their bed a beast the length of a man which had placed itself on him, and so heavy that he did not have the power to make the sign of the cross with his hand, but with the tip of his tongue, and that he had seen it enter through the door latch by the light of the moon
notable_quotes.context: Description of supernatural experience during illness Mongin André attributed to Jacquot

notable_quotes.speaker: priest at Berbenel (via hearsay)
notable_quotes.french: que celuy qui luy avoit donné le mal, avoit tasché de redoubler le sort pour luy faire perdre son fruict
notable_quotes.english: that the one who had given her the illness had tried to redouble the spell to make her lose her fruit
notable_quotes.context: Told to Françoise fille Jean Mulot about her bewitchment

relationships.evidence_text: his wife; Jacquot and his wife
Jacquot's daughter (now married at St Nicolas)
son of Jacquot; Mongin André had beaten son of Jacquot
7 years earlier had married Françoise fille Jean Mulot
His daughter, wife of Jacques Barbey
Her father in law Dedier André

relationships.person2: Mengeotte femme Jean Mulot le jeune

relationships.evidence_text: Had had a niece ill in his house for 4 years
gave it to his son's dog
Said his sister had lent Didier André 25 or 30 francs

economic_context.details: Jacquot's sister lent Didier André 25-30 francs and André was angry when she wanted repayment; quarrel over garden between Dedier André and Jacquot; Pierot Poirson refused to rent land to Jacquot; woodland dispute where Jacquot was obliged to leave 'baliveaux' but someone else cut them, obliged to pay 55 francs damages; theft accusation (falsely accused of stealing cloth); Jacquot described as draper who left Hymont to make better living at Lorquin; Aubry Picquaud described as bankrupt

harms_catalog.harm_description: died after eating hay bought from Jacquot
mostly as if rabid; Jacquot helped drag them out of stable
lightning struck house, making hole in wall, fell between witness, wife, and Jacquot
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: witness found him lighting fire to cook on eve of St Bartholomew and told him day was too dangerous to cook on

harms_catalog.harm_description: dead within a month
ruined along with his children before his death
always ill during 4 years together; swelled as she approached village so 'ceinture' of 'garderobe' broke; given 'un mauvais regard' near washing place
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: refusal to act or be invited as godparent

harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: after quarrel, continued after selling garden

harms_catalog.victim_relationship_to_witness: family of father-in-law (Barbe veuve Claudon André)
harms_catalog.harm_description: 6 people dying 'seiches et arides'

harms_catalog.victim_relationship_to_witness: witness's son's dog (Epurot Mulot le viel)
harms_catalog.harm_description: left and was never seen again after eating tart piece left by Jacquot

harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: few days after fine, 9-10 years ago

harms_catalog.harm_description: became ill and died after 18 months
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Claude killed a hen belonging to Jacquot which got into their garden

harms_catalog.harm_description: illness lasted 2 years; always swollen, grew until like a barrel with 'venin' coming from tip
died during illness described as 'un mal donné'
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: killed hen after Jacquot's hens continually damaged garden; Jacquot knocked unripe apples off trees

harms_catalog.harm_description: fell ill in extraordinary fashion, stomach very swollen, lasted 3 weeks; recovered after Jacquot and wife visited
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: son called Jacquot's daughter 'noir bo' in play or annoyance

harms_catalog.harm_description: current spells
current spells

harms_catalog.victim_relationship_to_witness: witness's daughter (Mengeotte femme Jean Mulot le jeune)
harms_catalog.harm_description: adjudged possessed 3 weeks earlier
harms_catalog.attributed_to: Jacquot Petit Jacquot and his wife

harms_catalog.harm_description: diagnosed by Ambrosian father as bewitched; recovered after witness threatened to become partie formelle
became swollen under breasts around midday every day; seemed like an animal like a 'bouchon' moving there, causing such pain she was as if dead; exorcised by curé at Dommartin
harms_catalog.attributed_to: Jacquot Petit Jacquot or his wife
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: he had long wished witness ill and wanted to ruin him

harms_catalog.harm_description: horses became wild passing Jacquot's house; one bit him on arm and did not let go until got them home (showed scar)
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: killed two of Jacquot's hens which were always taking grain

harms_catalog.harm_description: smith said could not cure because poisoned; died after Jacquot mounted small son on it
harms_catalog.method_alleged: mounted small son on it and gave him a few turns

harms_catalog.harm_description: horse went wild loading in woods, thrown from cart, log fell on him and injured ribs; Jacquot emerged, said 'tant pis', went away
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: was very angry when witness refused to rent him land; passed on way to woods giving bonjour to companion but not to witness

harms_catalog.harm_description: whirlwind enveloped him, horses ran away, cartwheels passed over his body
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Jacquot had sown corn in field of witness; he cut it
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: as he was taking sheaves back

harms_catalog.victim_relationship_to_witness: late Claudon Andreu's father's horse (Jean Poirel)
harms_catalog.harm_description: died 2-3 days after Jacquot asked which was best
became ill after Jacquot and wife complained; priest at Vittel told her illness might have been given by a witch
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: cloth was stolen, several falsely charged Jacquot, Jacquot and wife complained bitterly to witness

harms_catalog.victim_relationship_to_witness: witness's daughter (Claudon femme Demenge le Clerc)
harms_catalog.harm_description: possessed; at exorcism by curé of Berbenal devil said a man had made him enter her without naming him

harms_catalog.harm_description: losses of animals
taken ill as he was putting up ladder, died in 2 weeks

harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: 21 years before, taken ill after going to see Jacquot

harms_catalog.harm_description: 'escorcheur' told her they were full of poison
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: dispute at mill when Jacquot tried to go before her although she was first

harms_catalog.victim_relationship_to_witness: witness's first husband (Claude femme Claudot l'Huillier)
harms_catalog.harm_description: long illness for a year; saw beast length of a man enter bed by door latch in moonlight, so heavy could only make sign of cross with tip of tongue; would not go to bed without candle and holy water; died
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: before their marriage he had beaten son of Jacquot
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: after beating, long illness for a year

harms_catalog.victim_name: Jean Mulot le jeune of Hymont
harms_catalog.victim_relationship_to_witness: employer (Jean Mulot jeune fils de Mattaincourt)
harms_catalog.harm_description: fell ill, reckoned to be bewitched; recovered in 2 days after witness threatened to beat Jacquot
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: quarrel with Jean Mulot who wanted to send Jacquot away while with soldiers

material_culture.context: 2 calves died after eating hay bought from Jacquot
sick boy had blessed candle in hand all day
Mongin André would not go to bed without holy water beside him; people came to sprinkle holy water at funeral
Jacquot broke a tart in 4 and shared it; witness feared poisoning and gave his part to dog
wife chased witness with knife in hand
Françoise came out with stick in hand
Dedier Roy taken ill as he was putting up ladder for building
loading grain on cart; passed with cart on way to woods; cartwheels passed over body
loading grain on cart; going to mill with 2 horses to fetch flour; hens taking grain
cloth belonging to witness was stolen
Jacquot's daughter was making lace in witness's house
sick boy called out for some bread during night, ate it readily
Jacquot's sister lent Didier André this amount
Jacquot obliged to pay 55 francs in damages for woodland dispute
broke when Françoise swelled approaching village

spatial_references.context: Primary location of trial; where accused was native and most witnesses lived
Where father was executed; where witches were held who might denounce Jacquot; where Françoise was exorcised; where Messire Jean Chrestofle was located
Where Jacquot fled to work with dyer; where he lived for 4 months
Road to Bazoilles where Jacquot was captured
Where Jacquot's daughter was married; pilgrimage destination
Pilgrimage destination where Françoise was told about spell; where daughter was exorcised
Pilgrimage destination
Location of Mre Jean de la Montaigne who could identify who gave illness
Where curé exorcised Aubry Picquaud's wife
Pilgrimage Jacquot promised to make during torture
Pilgrimage destination where priest told about witchcraft
Where man who stole cloth was executed
Where Claude femme Claudot l'Huillier lived
Home of Jean Mulot jeune fils
Where Jacquot was serving in M de Florainville's regiment waiting for Mansfeld
Reference to son of governor of Nancy
Where Jacquot gave Françoise 'un mauvais regard'
Where drinking and sharing tart occurred
Going to mill with horses; dispute over priority at mill
Where Jacquot committed offences and was fined; where loading occurred and injury happened
Where Jacquot's daughter saw great black bull; where Jacquot approached horse; where corn was sown
Dispute over garden between Dedier André and Jacquot; hen got into garden; garden being auctioned; apples knocked off trees

historical_context.military_details: Jacquot served in M de Florainville's regiment waiting for Mansfeld at Nommeny; 4 years before had been with soldiers under son of governor of Nancy where Jacquot was in service
economic_hardship_indicators: Dedier André ruined along with his children
Jacquot left Hymont to make better living at Lorquin
since death of horse witness 'n'a jamais heu heur ny chanse'

prior_legal_disputes.description: Several falsely charged Jacquot with stealing cloth (actually stolen by man executed at Vallefroicourt); Jacquot complained bitterly
Woodland offences - obliged to leave 'baliveaux' but someone else cut them
prior_legal_disputes.outcome: Jacquot obliged to pay 55 francs in damages

legal_context.redress_outcome: Messire Poirson forbade him from taking vengeance; when he addressed Poirson as head of justice against someone who called him witch, Poirson made them both be held as good men and they went drinking together with alderman

change_de_nancy.modification_details: Approved torture (question ordinaire et extraordinaire) as requested by PG des Vosges

hearsay_chains.content: threatened he would make him 'le plus pauvre homme de sa race'
heard from Messire Jean Chrestofle that Jacquot said he would have himself arrested for witchcraft if not for shame
thought accused had caused death of his wife
when guarding father's horses Jacquot asked which was best and it died 2-3 days later
learned from others that wife's suspicion was on account of refusal to act as godparent
told wife that one who gave illness tried to redouble spell to make her lose fruit
story about great black bull that disappeared
had heard some noise that son would recover
heard her accuse him over illness of her son
diagnosed son-in-law as bewitched by the accused
told him that when in fields Jacquot approached, asked which horse was best, mounted small son on it
said could not cure horse because it was poisoned
told wife illness might have been given by a witch
devil said a man had made him enter daughter without naming him
all testimony about his illness and supernatural experiences

hearsay_chains.source: those who came to sprinkle holy water
hearsay_chains.content: remarked husband was in peace and week earlier had been quarrelling with Jacquot
told her dead animals were full of poison

emotional_state_notes: vilified and indignant at common rumors
wife wanted to preserve honor of daughter
called on patron saints during torture

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: François Mecquart had paid fines to duke
Michiel Collin had insulted a man in court and been forced to retract
Aubry Picquard had cut wood he was supposed to protect, and was bankrupt
Jean Mulot le viel had paid fines, and was a thief
Mengeotte femme Jean Mulot le jeune had been troubled in mind and should not be heard; husband had paid fines
Jean Mulot was already ill when he came to regiment
Claude femme Claudot l'Huillier had stolen some eggs

third_parties.name: Jacquot Petit Jacquot (father)
third_parties.context: Already executed at Mirecourt for witchcraft; repeatedly mentioned as establishing reputation

third_parties.name: mother of Jacquot
third_parties.context: Suspected of witchcraft (witness 29)

third_parties.name: Dedier André (Didier André, Dedier Andreu)
third_parties.context: Quarrelled with Jacquot over garden and debt; lost animals and family members; accused Jacquot; later ruined with children before his death

third_parties.name: Françoise fille Jean Mulot
third_parties.relationship_to_witness: daughter of witness 8, wife of witness 3
third_parties.context: Died believing Jacquot bewitched her; illness lasted 2-4 years; swollen like barrel

third_parties.name: Claude Cabled
third_parties.relationship_to_witness: son of witness 14, brother of witnesses 7 and 9
third_parties.context: Killed Jacquot's hen, became ill and died after 18 months

third_parties.name: Ambrosian father
third_parties.context: Exorcised niece of Abraham Hilaire; diagnosed Jean Poirel as bewitched by accused

third_parties.name: Messire Jean Chrestofle
third_parties.context: Previously vicaire of Hymont, now at Mirecourt; allegedly heard Jacquot say he would have himself arrested for witchcraft if not for shame

third_parties.name: Mre Jean de la Montaigne
third_parties.context: Of Bayon; could identify who gave illness

third_parties.name: priest at Berbenel
third_parties.context: Told Françoise that one who gave illness tried to redouble spell

third_parties.name: curé of Berbenal
third_parties.context: Exorcised daughter of Claudon femme Demenge le Clerc

third_parties.name: curé at Dommartin
third_parties.context: Exorcised Aubry Picquaud's wife

third_parties.name: priest at Vittel
third_parties.context: Told Jean Marchand Didelot's wife that illness might have been given by witch

third_parties.name: Mongin André
third_parties.context: Beat son of Jacquot, then suffered long illness with supernatural manifestations; died

third_parties.name: Dedier Roy
third_parties.context: Hired Jacquot for building, taken ill putting up ladder, died in 2 weeks, 21 years earlier

third_parties.name: Claudon Andreu (Claudon André)
third_parties.context: Told Jean Poirel about horse dying after Jacquot asked which was best

third_parties.name: wife of Jacquot
third_parties.context: Implicated alongside Jacquot in some testimony; chased witness with knife; wanted to preserve honor of daughter

third_parties.name: daughter of Jacquot
third_parties.context: Now married at St Nicolas; was making lace; told story about black bull; called 'noir bo' by child

third_parties.name: son of Jacquot
third_parties.context: Beaten by Mongin André who then fell ill and died

third_parties.name: sister of Jacquot
third_parties.context: Lent Didier André 25-30 francs

third_parties.name: late grandmother of Jacques Clerc
third_parties.context: Told Jacques Clerc that none of children of late Jacquot Petit Jacquot resembled him so much in every way

third_parties.name: Jean Mulot le jeune of Hymont
third_parties.context: Employer of Jacquot with soldiers; quarrelled with him and fell ill; recovered after threat to Jacquot

third_parties.name: taincturier (dyer) of Lorquin
third_parties.context: Jacquot went to work with him at Lorquin

third_parties.name: M de Florainville
third_parties.context: Military commander whose regiment Jacquot served in at Nommeny waiting for Mansfeld

third_parties.name: Mansfeld
third_parties.context: Military figure referenced in context of regiment

third_parties.name: son of governor of Nancy
third_parties.context: Commander of soldiers where Jacquot served 4 years earlier

third_parties.name: man executed at Vallefroicourt
third_parties.context: Actually stole cloth that Jacquot was falsely accused of stealing

third_parties.name: Epurot Mulot le jeune
third_parties.context: Wife quarrelled with Jacquot and his wife; garden being auctioned

third_parties.name: miller's wife
third_parties.context: Gave priority to Margueritte veuve Dedier Roy at mill despite Jacquot trying to go first

third_parties.context: Told Margueritte that dead animals were full of poison

third_parties.context: Told Estienne Collin he could not cure horse because it was poisoned

third_parties.name: servant of Estienne Collin
third_parties.context: Told about Jacquot approaching horse in fields and mounting son on it

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a highly detailed trial with 32 witnesses testifying over multiple days. Jacquot withstood torture without confessing and was ultimately released (renvoyé). His father had been executed for witchcraft, creating a long-standing reputation. Multiple witnesses reported quarrels followed by harms. Key patterns include: animal deaths, human illnesses and deaths, property damage, and supernatural manifestations. Jacquot fled to Lorquin but was captured when he returned. The trial includes extensive confrontations where Jacquot challenged witness credibility. Notable for the accused's survival despite extensive testimony and use of torture. Military context mentioned (Florainville's regiment, Mansfeld). Multiple exorcisms and pilgrimages mentioned. Economic disputes (debts, property, fines) feature prominently. Trial lasted over 17 months from initial warrant to release.
